componentInstanceProperties.name: bannerTitle
componentInstanceProperties.value: Investing 101: What You Need to Know Before You Start

componentInstanceProperties.name: richTextValue
componentInstanceProperties.value:
Investing, when done well, can be an effective way to build long-term wealth. The problem is, many people aren’t sure how or where to get started. And of the many people who could invest, many consider nothing beyond high interest bank accounts or real estate. 

So, if you’re thinking about investing but not sure where to start, here’s a beginner’s guide to investing to give you the basics plus common wealth-building strategies other investors typically employ at different life stages.

componentInstanceProperties.name: richTextValue
componentInstanceProperties.value: Why Investing is Important: a Primer on Wealth Building

componentInstanceProperties.name: richTextValue
componentInstanceProperties.value:
“Compound interest is the eighth wonder of the world. He who understands it, earns it ... he who doesn't ... pays it.” - Albert Einstein.

Gone are the days when saving for retirement was enough. To ensure your future wealth, you need to invest. Unlike saving, investing allows you the opportunity to earn a higher return over a longer period to combat inflation.

Over time, inflation erodes cash’s purchasing power. This is especially true when inflation is as high as it is today. According to Finder’s Cost of Living Report 2023, the average household was spending $185 a week on groceries, up $37 compared to the same month 12 months earlier. 

Historically, the stock market's average annual return is 10% before inflation, higher than many other asset classes. But many people shy away from investing because they think it’s too risky or they don’t know how to invest. While investing has inherent risk, there are investment strategies such as diversification (exposure to lots of different companies) that can minimise this risk and better equip you to achieve your financial goals. 

Really, anyone can invest. You don’t need to wait until you have enough time or many thousands of dollars to start. You don’t have to wait until the market is “heating up” or “cooling down.” Many people find investing daunting, but thanks to the WealthTech revolution, it’s now possible to invest small amounts over multiple assets to optimise returns. And even if all you do is buy shares on the stock market through a broker or a superannuation fund, thanks to compound interest, your investments should reap returns over the long-term, even in the face of market ups and downs.

What is compound interest? Picture a snowball of money growing larger and larger as it rolls down a hill. As interest accumulates on your initial investment, it adds to your ball of cash. You continue to earn interest, your investment increases in value and on it goes.

componentInstanceProperties.name: richTextValue
richTextValue
componentInstanceProperties.value:
There are seven common entry points to investing:

#1 Individual stocks

Stocks are shares in the ownership of a company or investments on which a fixed amount of interest is paid (e.g. dividends). When you invest in stocks, you’re hoping the company grows and performs well over time. If a stock you own on a stock exchange becomes valuable, you could earn a profit if you decide to sell it to another investor. Most people invest in stocks online through a brokerage account. 

Buying individual stocks requires thorough research and due diligence, as they are considered risky, especially if you do not have a diversified portfolio. On VentureCrowd we sometimes offer IPO deals via our platform. The benefit to investors is that they can invest at the opening price before a company hits the public market. Investments on stock exchanges are heavily regulated because they’re accessible to retail investors who don’t generally have as much finance expertise as wholesale and professional investors, so it’s worth familiarising yourself with how they work before you dive in.

#2 Private equity shares

Another option that has become more accessible in the last 10 years is to buy shares in private companies, from early-stage through to Series C. These investments offer higher risks and potential rewards than shares purchased via the stock exchange, and are less regulated, generally speaking. However, thanks to governments introducing equity crowdfunding legislation, platforms like VentureCrowd allow individual investors (both retail and wholesale) to spread their risk by offering the opportunity to invest in higher-risk and early-stage deals with smaller amounts of money. In most cases, these investments are illiquid, meaning you can’t sell your shares to another person or entity. However, sometimes you can transfer shares by paying a fee. 

#3 Mutual funds

A mutual fund (also known as a managed fund) is an investment fund that pools together money from many investors to purchase securities like stocks and bonds. An example of this in Australia is a traditional superannuation fund. The major benefit of mutual funds is that it gives you an efficient way to diversify your portfolio without having to select individual stocks or bonds. They cover most asset classes and you have the convenience of having what’s known as a Fund Manager overseeing the Fund’s performance and researching and selecting securities for you. 

#4 Bonds

Governments and companies often offer bonds to investors to fund the development of major infrastructure projects and growth initiatives. When you invest in bonds, you’re effectively lending money to the company or government. These are what we refer to as fixed-income investments, because, in return, you attract regular interest payments, often called coupon payments. Bonds are considered less risky than other growth assets and are a good way to diversify your portfolio. Bonds also provide a predictable income stream as they typically pay interest regularly, from monthly to half-yearly. 

#5 Cryptocurrency

A high-risk and less regulated option is to purchase cryptocurrency assets via a cryptocurrency exchange. With the rise of millennial investors, incorporating cryptocurrency into investment portfolios is becoming more common. 

One of the draw cards is that you can often invest in crypto with minimal amounts. However, the crypto market is extremely volatile and there’s a bit of a learning curve to understand how it works, so it’s worth following companies you’re interested in and thoroughly reviewing their white papers and use cases before investing. As the crypto market becomes more regulated and secondary markets become more commonplace, investing in crypto is likely to become more mainstream.

#6 Property

Property is probably the primary way people invest. However, nowadays there are many ways to dive into the market that don’t involve saving for a deposit and paying thousands in stamp duty. At VentureCrowd, you can invest across a range of property development and acquisition deals at different stages of the property capital stack.

Property investments involve a range of options from equity in building acquisitions—which provide a rental return and potential capital upside after the building’s sale—to fixed-income investments such as preference shares and first mortgage fund investments. If investing in property through a fund (including crowdfunding platforms), it’s important to understand the different development stages and diversify accordingly to spread your risk. Learn more about property investment through VentureCrowd here.

#7 Exchange-traded funds (ETFs)

ETFs are a diversified collection of assets (like a mutual fund) that trade on an exchange (like a share). This means investors can purchase them for a share price that is often less than the minimum investment many mutual funds require. Because of this, ETFs are great for beginner investors who are new to the stock market and also tend to be less risky than investing in individual stocks. Thanks to digital platforms, it’s possible to follow and learn from other investors.

componentInstanceProperties.name: richTextValue
componentInstanceProperties.value: Startups that have strong leadership and expertise behind them

componentInstanceProperties.name: richTextValue
componentInstanceProperties.value: Startups that have very strong leadership teams, lead investors and advisors are well placed to accelerate into the next economic cycle. Companies that are led by purpose-driven founders with deep domain expertise in the industry are highly attractive to investors. However, recent events have shown that just having big investor names behind a brand is no longer enough. This must be married with results.

componentInstanceProperties.name: richTextValue
componentInstanceProperties.value: How To Get Started with Investing

componentInstanceProperties.name: richTextValue
componentInstanceProperties.value:
Ready to explore investing? For your information, here are four easy steps many investors take to get started:

1. Determine your investment goals

Are you looking for a long-term investment strategy, or do you want your portfolio to generate regular passive income? Knowing this will narrow down your investment options and simplify the process.

Consider your ultimate goal for this money—is it for retirement? A down payment on a house in the next few years? 

2. Decide how much you want to invest

How much you invest will depend on your current financial situation, investment goal and when you want to reach it.

Say that your investment goal is to generate money for retirement. As a general rule of thumb, you will probably want to invest 10% to 15% of your income each year for retirement. For other investment goals such as a house deposit, travel or education, consider your timeline and the amount of money you need, then work your way backwards to break the amount down into weekly/monthly investments. 

3. Pick an investment strategy

Your investment strategy depends on your investment goals. If your goal is long term (i.e. 20 years from now) then stocks and private equity could be a big part of your strategy. Many people choose to do this via mutual funds, bonds or ETFs. 

If you’re saving for a short-term goal such as a down payment on a house 5 years from now, then you may be better off investing in a low-risk investment portfolio options such as short-term bond funds, low-risk fixed income investments with shorter terms or high interest savings accounts. 

4. Open an investment account

Once you’ve defined your goal and investment strategies, you can compare brokerage accounts and other digital investment platforms to choose the right one for you based on your risk profile and financial situation. 

Digital investment platforms like VentureCrowd have revolutionised the way individuals can invest their money. These platforms provide a range of investment options, including private equity, property, and fixed income investments, which can be accessed with just a few clicks of a button.

Signing up for an investment account with VentureCrowd is simple and can be done in a matter of minutes. Once you have registered, you can start browsing and investing in a range of asset classes, with the added benefit of fractional investing. This means that you can invest small amounts of money in high-quality assets that were previously only accessible to institutional investors or high net worth individuals.

Besides the ease of use and access to a range of investment options, digital investment platforms like VentureCrowd also generally offer lower fees than traditional brokerage accounts. This is because they operate with lower overheads and can pass these savings onto their customers.

With choosing the right investment account, factor in the following:

  • The type of brokerage account you need
  • The brokerage account fees/associated costs involved
  • The features you need/want

componentInstanceProperties.name: richTextValue
componentInstanceProperties.value:
Before deciding to invest, you need to first assess your personal risk tolerance. Risk management in investing refers to identifying the potential risks of each investment and conducting your due diligence to see how much of your investment you can really afford to lose. Risk is a normal part of investing, yet some investment types carry more risk than others. These risks typically relate to things like market volatility and economic downturns. Fortunately, besides doing your research, there are some other ways to reduce risk when investing.

You’ve seen us mention “diversification” quite a bit so far. Diversification in investing is choosing more than one investment across different asset classes so that if one asset takes a loss, your other investments won’t be affected. Diversifying your investment portfolio is a smart investment strategy to offset risk and keep your money safe.

Remember, with investing, there’s what’s known as “risk vs. reward”. Simply put, if you are prepared to take greater risks, then you should earn greater rewards. That means investments with the potential to return the most also usually have the potential to lose the most if something were to happen to the current state of the market.

You want to invest according to the risk level that’s right for you. Based on your timelines and how much risk you can, well, risk, you can then determine whether you want a high-risk or low-risk investment type.

componentInstanceProperties.name: richTextValue
richTextValue
componentInstanceProperties.value: Investment Strategies for Different Life Stages

componentInstanceProperties.name: richTextValue
componentInstanceProperties.value:
Your investing strategy will largely depend on what stage of life you’re at. Let’s look at some common life stages and what investments may suit.

Ages 25-35: Around this age, most people are completing higher education and getting started in their careers. Investment goals generally centre around things like travel, putting down payments on property and funding education. Another form of investment to consider in today's digital world is micro and digital investing. With the rise of crowdfunding and crypto, investors can now take part in small-scale investments with the potential for high returns. These digital natives are very comfortable with platforms which offer fractional investing in a mix of fixed income, convertible notes, and ordinary equity investing.

Ages 35-45: This age group tends to be more secure in their careers and have investment goals centred around raising families, buying a house and covering daily living costs. Crowdfunding has become an increasingly popular investment alternative for those in the 35-45 age group who wish to invest periodically without requiring a lot of money upfront. With crowdfunding, individuals can invest in startups or small businesses and potentially earn returns on their investment. This can be a great way to diversify your portfolio and support emerging businesses that align with your values.

In addition to crowdfunding, this age group may also want to consider investing in property through real estate investment trusts (REITs) or rental properties. This can provide a steady stream of income while also building equity over time.

Ages 45-55: In this age group, the focus is on accumulating money for retirement. Think about allocating funds to various investment instruments including bonds, stocks, superannuation and other mutual funds as well as diversifying with fractional investing in a mix of equity and fixed income investing.

Ages 55+: This age group is preparing for retirement and may also experience diminished income once they hit retirement age. To pay for daily needs, look at expanding your investment portfolio and move to more conservative, low-risk instruments that can provide you with a steady income such as bonds, and fixed income investments. 

At VentureCrowd we have something to offer investors at every stage of life, including easy, digital investing via our platform and the opportunity to invest smaller amounts across a range of curated and high-growth potential deals, from fixed income property deals to early and late stage private equity investments. 

As your financial goals and risk tolerance changes over time, you can adjust your investment portfolio as needed. Some ways you can rebalance your portfolio include selling high-performing investments and buying lower-performing ones, allocating additional money strategically until your portfolio is balanced and periodically checking your portfolio and making adjustments, if it’s shifted 5 percentage points or more from its target. Of course, the above is for your information only. It is always important to seek professional financial advice so you can adjust your investment strategy to suit your specific situation.

componentInstanceProperties.name: richTextValue
componentInstanceProperties.value: Fulfil your financial future with VentureCrowd

componentInstanceProperties.name: richTextValue
componentInstanceProperties.value:
Investment opportunities come in multiple asset classes. Understanding the different classes and aligning them with your current situation and short/long-term goals can help you decide what to invest in so that you can work toward your chosen investment target. 

Investing doesn’t have to be complex. The best practice for any beginner investor is to thoroughly research your options and look for low-cost, broadly diversified investment options to start building your portfolio. 

And if you want to join the WealthTech revolution, you can invest in Australian startups and alternative assets including high-growth private companies and property developments through our equity crowdfunding platform. Find out more about our current active deals and book a call with one of our friendly team members to discuss your investment strategy today.
